newsitem.title: GERMANY: Oil World sees rising soybean, soymeal imports.
newsitem.headline: Oil World sees rising soybean, soymeal imports.

text.p: Global soybean imports in October/March 1996/97 were forecast at 17.6 million tonnes, 1.6 million more than in the same 95/96 period, the independent Oil World newsletter said.
The publication said China, Taiwan, Japan, Brazil, Mexico, the EU, Poland and Russia would buy more beans, mostly from the U.S., ahead of Brazilian and Paraguayan exports from March.
The U.S. would account for 16 million of total imports in that period, shipping 1.3 million tonnes more than in 95/96.
In April-September 1997, Argentina, Brazil and Paraguay were seen exporting a combined 8.4 million tonnes of beans, 1.7 million more than in the same 1996 period.
U.S. exports in the same period should fall 300,000 tonnes to 7.7 million.
Oil World stresseed the forecast assumed favourable weather and a record crop in Latin America.
It also forecast global soymeal consumption in Oct/Sept 96/97 at 89.6 million tonnes, up 500,000 tonnes from its previous estimate and up 2.1 million tonnes from last season.
The rise would be driven by China and other Asian countries namely Philippines, Thailand, Indonesia, South Korea and Vietnam.
